newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE grains up as farmer sellers still reluctant.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE grains up as farmer sellers still reluctant.

text.p: LIFFE grains rose as an increasing number of would-be buyers failed to entice farmer sellers out of the woodwork.
May dominated trading in wheat, with 467 of the total 773 lots traded.
May wheat last changed hands at 100.10 stg, 1.40 stg higher and its high for the day.
November was the most active contract on barley, with 15 of a total 24 lots traded. It last traded 0.75 stg up at 93.50 stg.
Shipper buying indicated that there is some export optimism, one trader said. But potential sellers held back. "A lot of sellers I might have expected to see didn't want to play," he said.
The strength of futures is closely connected to a firm physical market, others said.
The market is strong despite a poor relative competitive position relative to other origins, they said.
"More people want to buy than want to sell, so you can't stop it going up," another trader said.
Consumer buyers were short on April/May and were getting nervous, she reckoned.
Farmers, on the other hand, were pretty well sold and were relaxed. The result was a strong market.
"The French market has picked up which helps," she said.

Demand for French wheat at the ports remained strong on Monday, underpinned by buyers looking to cover export needs. "It looks like we're in for another hot week," one French trader said. He was expecting continued price rises in the face of holding back by sellers.
The picture of a tighter than expected market Europe-wide was underlined by Guy Legras, the European Commission's chief permanent agriculture official.
He predicted on Monday that EU grain consumption would be higher than forecast this season, limiting the amount of grain ending up in intervention.
"There is a very strong increase in (EU) consumption. All the figures...show that there is a stronger increase than expected," he told Reuters by telephone from Brussels.
